comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: A beautiful color image of the same aircraft may be viewed on ‘flickr’ here: www.flickr.com/photos/20111203@N07/2274229161/ Low definition monochrome image of highly decorated and distinctively colorful Douglas F4D-1 Skyray Bu No 134802. Of “All Weather Fighter Squadron” VF(AW)-3 with tail code PA and ‘Modex’ 32 on nose. With small ‘NORAD’ badge applied behind cockpit. (North American Air Defense Command) It also carries a dark painted pod on outer wing-see notes below. Go here for a color profile of F4D-1 134802 as displayed in the picture above: wp.scn.ru/en/ww3/f/814/3/1/31 Go here for info on the F4D-1: www.joebaugher.com/navy_fighters/f6_2.html (many thanks to Professor Joe Baugher of Chicago, Illinois, USA) Relevant quotes from text; “The first Navy unit to receive Skyrays was Composite Squadron 3 (VC-3) based at NAS Moffett in California, which got its first planes on April 16, 1956. This outfit performed the initial service evaluation of the type. VC-3 was later redesignated VFAW-3, and was attached for a time to the Air Defense Command. While with the ADC, VFAW-3 was based at NAS North Island, San Diego, California. These aircraft participated in the aerial defense of the United States, and carried an electronics package on the fuselage centerline pylon, a pair of 300-gallon underwing drop tanks, a pack of 12 2.75-inch unguided rockets on each of the outer underwing pylons, and a Sidewinder air-to-missile on each of the wing root pylons.” More info on F4D-1 with three pictures of VFAW-3 F4D’s and info on Commanding Officer Eugene Valencia. www.ccdemo.info/AircraftPix/Skyray.html A passage from this webpage illustrates VFAW-3’s role succinctly: www.navalhistory.org/2010/04/29/flightdeck-friday-f4d-sky... NORAD Operations: “The Ford’s interceptor qualities (namely an unmatched climbing ability) were formally recognized when VF(AW)-3 was “chopped” to NORAD for continental defense. Flying out of San Diego, the squadron’s aircraft were painted in one of the better recognized schemes in an era of already colorful Naval aircraft. As the only Navy squadron, VFAW-3 twice won NORAD’s trophy for best performing unit, placing above USAF squadrons in the process. During this time, VFAW-3 was deployed to Key West for the Cuban Missile crisis. That and a deployment to Taiwan in 1958 were the nearest the Ford would get to combat action.” ((Navy slang for the F4D was 'Ford')) F4D-1 134802 was chosen for a subject by commercial model decal company “Eagle Strike” 1/72 scale set number 72-043 members.home.nl/thunderchief/modeling/pages/enf4d101.htm F4D-1 134802 was also chosen for a subject by commercial model decal company “Cutting Edge Decals” in a 1/48 scale set number CED48091 “1/48 F4D-1, 134802, PA32 of VFAW-3, Same as kit scheme, except SEPARATE YELLOW STARS! You paint the fin and spine blue and add the yellow stars. More stars on this a/c than the kit decal subject. Very attractive a/c!” There is as yet no other known internet reference to F4D-1 134802.
